proposals.reasoning: This matches the broad consensus from the table for a low-drama opener, keeps the first mission simple, and avoids including anyone who has been pushing too hard to be on the team. Alice+Diana has been explicitly supported by multiple players, so it should get good buy-in and give us an early result without unnecessary suspicion or chaos.

votes.comment: Safe enough opener with me on it; if it fails Diana is immediately under heavy suspicion, giving us strong early info.
Team matches broad consensus for a low-info, low-drama Mission 1 and neither Alice nor Diana has raised any early red flags.
Standard low-info Mission 1 team; both Alice and Diana fit the calm, low-drama opener we wanted, and there’s no strong reason to deviate yet.
I’m fine with the low-drama opener and being on the first mission to build early trust.
This matches my stated preference for a low-drama opener and has broad consensus; no reason to force early chaos on Mission 1.
Both widely trusted and includes my evil teammate; good low-suspicion opener for us.

discussion.content: For a 2-person first mission I’d rather start simple and low-drama: I’m happy to go, and I slightly prefer pairing with someone who hasn’t been overly eager yet, like Charlie or Diana. Early on I think we should avoid anyone pushing too hard to be included until we see a bit more table behavior.
I’m fine keeping it low-key to start—between Charlie and Diana I’ve slightly liked Diana’s calmer openings in past games, so I’d lean you + Diana for Mission 1.

I’m good with keeping it simple and like the sound of Alice + Diana to start, since both tend to play pretty steady early. With a 2-person opener we mostly just want a team that won’t overreact either way to the result, and that pair fits.
Alice + me is fine for a low-info opener, but if people are nervous about putting the chooser on the team, I’d also be comfortable with Alice + Charlie as a solid alternative.
Alice + Diana works for me as a calm, low-drama opener, and I’d rather not overcomplicate Mission 1. If people are uneasy about that, Alice + Charlie feels like a fine backup.

Alice + Diana seems like a solid, low-noise opener to me, and I’d rather not overthink Mission 1. If that somehow doesn’t pass, I’d still want Alice on the team and probably swap between Charlie/Diana next.

proposals.reasoning: We should anchor off the clean Mission 1 by keeping exactly one of Alice/Diana, not both, to avoid re-using the same unchecked pair. Including myself (Bob) is standard for information and accountability, and adding Charlie gives us a fresh, untested player while only changing one member from the previous success. If this team passes, Alice and Charlie both look better; if it fails, we immediately know that at least one of Alice/Bob/Charlie is evil and can compare everyone’s prior preferences to refine reads.

votes.comment: Anchors off the clean Mission 1 with one of the original pair and adds a new player for info; reasonable early-game team with no obvious red flags.
Team builds off the clean Mission 1 by keeping Alice as anchor, includes me for accountability, and tests Charlie; good early-info team with no obvious structural red flags.
I’d rather keep the proven Alice–Diana pair together and add a single new player than swap Diana out for Bob, which increases the risk of introducing two unknowns at once.
Consistent with my earlier preference to keep Alice as anchor and add Charlie; including Bob isn’t ideal info-wise but still a reasonable early team.
Early mission with one anchor from the clean team and one new player; even if it fails, it gives useful info about Bob/Charlie vs the Alice–Diana pair.
Solid anchor off the clean Mission 1 with just one of Alice/Diana and some fresh info on Bob/Charlie, even though I’d have preferred a version including myself for extra data.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 passed, I’d like to keep at least one of Alice/Diana on the next team and add someone who hasn’t been tested yet, like Charlie or Eve, rather than reshuffling everything. We shouldn’t hard-clear anyone off one success, but building off a known success feels safer than starting from scratch.

I like anchoring off the clean first mission too, so I’d definitely keep at least one of Alice/Diana. Between untested players, I slightly prefer adding Charlie first and seeing how that combo behaves, rather than changing too many variables at once.

I’m good sticking with at least one of Alice/Diana as an anchor from the clean first mission, and I don’t mind being the new addition if we want fresh info. Between the two, I’d slightly rather keep Diana on for now just so we’re not repeating the exact same leader + team combo.

I’m fine using Mission 1 as an anchor and I slightly prefer keeping Alice on with a new addition like Charlie, so we get fresh info without throwing out what we already know. If people are worried about repeating the exact same combo, I’m also okay with swapping me in for Alice instead.

I’m on board with using the Mission 1 pair as an anchor, but I’d actually like to see Alice + Diana + one new person rotated in over the next two missions, starting with adding me or Charlie now so we get clearer comparisons later.
I’d rather not repeat the exact Alice–Diana pair yet, so I’d lean toward a team like Alice + Charlie + me to keep one anchor from Mission 1 while getting fresh info on two new links.

proposals.reasoning: We’re 2–0 with no fails, and the only tested configurations so far are Alice–Diana (Mission 1) and Alice–Bob–Charlie (Mission 2), both clean. Keeping Alice/Bob/Charlie as the core preserves the most trusted structure we have, and adding Diana—who has already been on a successful mission with Alice—minimizes the number of new, untested variables on a potential game‑winning mission. Bringing in Eve or Frank would introduce extra uncertainty for no added benefit when a low‑variance, high‑confidence team is available.

votes.comment: We’re 2–0 with no fails, this keeps the proven core together and adds the only other previously clean player rather than introducing an untested risk on a potential game-winning mission.
All four members have been on at least one clean mission configuration already; this is the lowest‑risk, most information-consistent team for a potential game‑winning quest.

Two clean missions with Alice/Bob/Charlie as core strongly suggest they’re good; adding previously clean Diana is the lowest-risk way to try to win on Mission 3 without introducing an untested player.

Consistent with my earlier reasoning: this keeps the proven Alice/Bob/Charlie core and reuses me as the already-tested fourth, avoiding introducing extra uncertainty on a potential game-deciding mission.
All four have only appeared in clean mission combinations so far; statistically safest low-variance team from my POV as good.
Team is consistent with prior clean cores and keeps variance low; no strong reason to shake this up now.

discussion.content: Given we’re 2–0 with no fails, I’d rather stick close to what’s already worked—Alice, Bob, Charlie feel fine to me—and add just one new person, probably Eve, rather than shake things up too much.
Sticking with Alice/Bob/Charlie as a core makes sense to me, and between the new picks I slightly prefer adding Diana since she’s already been on a clean mission and Frank is still a total unknown.

I’m good sticking with the Alice/Bob/Charlie core for now, and between the extras I lean Diana as the safer add since she’s already been on a clean team with Alice. I’d rather leave Frank off one more mission until we have to test him.

Given how clean the first two missions have been, I’m comfortable keeping Alice/Bob/Charlie as the core and adding me again as the tested fourth rather than pulling in a totally untested Frank right now. That gives us the most info with the least disruption.

I’m fine with keeping the Alice/Bob/Charlie core and adding Diana here—between the two clean missions, that’s the lowest‑risk four we’ve got. I don’t think we need to force‑test Frank or me on the potential game‑winning mission.
Sticking with the Alice/Bob/Charlie core plus Diana feels like the lowest‑variance choice here—no reason to introduce a totally untested player like me on a potential game‑deciding mission.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie was clean, but Mission 3 failed when I was added, so I understand the suspicion on me. However, locking in the exact Mission 2 trio again only confirms what we already mostly know and doesn’t give extra information if something unexpected happens. Swapping Charlie for Frank keeps the trusted core of Alice and Bob while testing a new third who hasn’t been on any failed mission. If this team passes, it both secures the quest and strongly points to me as the problem; if it fails, it forces us to reconsider assumptions about the Mission 2 trio rather than tunneling purely on the ‘add Diana = fail’ narrative.

votes.comment: Frank is totally untested while the Alice–Bob–Charlie trio already passed clean as a 3-person team; with the score 2–1, this is not the time to introduce a new risk instead of reusing the proven combo.
Mission 2’s Alice-Bob-Charlie trio is our highest-confidence good team; swapping in unknown Frank just to gain ‘information’ risks introducing an evil when we mainly need a clean success now.

Both Alice and Frank previously preferred rerunning the Mission 2 trio (Alice, Bob, Charlie); this Diana-led swap to add Frank over me goes against that implied Merlin logic and feels like evil trying to insert a partner.
My inclusion last round is already seen as suspicious, so a team without me but with my evil ally Frank going is ideal; we want this to pass the table so evil can sabotage.
Re-running the proven-clean Mission 2 trio (Alice, Bob, Charlie) is safer; swapping in Frank adds an unnecessary unknown when we’re already at 2-1 and can likely win with the established team.
I’m fine being tested here; it keeps the trusted Alice–Bob core while adding fresh info compared to just rerunning Mission 2.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie was a clean success with 0 fails. Mission 3 only changed by adding Diana and then produced a single fail, making Diana the most likely new evil variable. With the score at 2–1 and this mission being critical, the highest-probability good team is to rerun the proven Mission 2 trio rather than introduce new uncertainty by adding Diana, Frank, or myself.

votes.comment: Rerunning the same trio that just produced a hidden fail risk feels too trusting of the 'blame Diana' narrative; I’d rather see at least one swap (e.g., trying Eve) than lock in a combo that could easily hide a patient evil from Mission 2.
Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean, and the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, so this is our highest-confidence good team right now.
Mission 2 with this exact trio was clean; Mission 3 only failed when Diana was added, so this is the highest-probability good team at a critical point.

It’s very likely good, but if Diana was framed by a single fail, we should at least consider that one of Alice/Bob/Charlie could have passed intentionally on Mission 2. Locking this back in without testing Eve or Frank gives us no new info if it passes and ends the game if it’s wrong.
Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie was clean; the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, so rerunning the proven trio is the highest-probability good team right now.

ABC looks clean from past data, but locking in that trio without testing anyone else after a single fail on the 4-person team feels too rigid; I’d rather see a mix that gives us new info (e.g., swapping in Eve or Frank) instead of auto-repeating Mission 2.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie is our only fully-tested 3-player team that succeeded cleanly, and Mission 3 only failed when Diana was added to that same core. Given the current stakes, the safest and most consistent choice is to rerun the Mission 2 trio, keep Diana off, and avoid introducing new variables like Eve or myself when we already have a proven combination.

votes.comment: ABC must contain the single unknown evil from {Alice,Bob,Charlie,Diana}, so this team is guaranteed to have 1 evil on it and risks a critical fail.

Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie is our only clean 3-player team; the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, and broad consensus (except Diana) is to keep her off, so this is the safest choice.

Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and me is our only clean 3-player team; Mission 3 only failed when Diana was added, and both Merlin candidates are backing this trio, so this is our best shot to close the game.
All three have been heavily townread; passing this likely gives good their third success and leaves evil relying only on a risky assassination.
Re-running the only clean tested trio (Alice, Bob, Charlie) is safest; the only change on the failed mission was adding Diana, so this team minimizes new risk.
All three have looked consistently good after the clean Mission 2; I’d rather not lock in a likely all-good team at 2–1 and would prefer to see a different mix tested.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and Charlie is our only 3-player team that has passed cleanly, and the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana. Re-running the Mission 2 trio keeps the composition with the strongest track record while avoiding introducing new uncertainty from Diana, Eve, or Frank at this critical point.

votes.comment: Mission 2 with this exact trio passed cleanly, and the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, so statistically this is still our best shot.
Mission 2’s Alice–Bob–Charlie trio is our only clean 3-player team; the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, so this is the safest choice at a critical point.

Mission 2 with Alice, Bob, and me is the only clean 3-player team, and the only change on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana. Re-running the proven trio is the highest-percentage play for good here.

It’s too locked-in on the Mission 2 trio off a single fail datapoint; I’d rather see at least one slot flexed (e.g., testing Eve or Frank) before we commit what could be the deciding mission to the exact same group.

ABC is the only proven clean 3-player combo so far; the failed mission’s only change was adding Diana, so re-running Alice, Bob, and Charlie is the most statistically reliable good team at this point.
All three (Alice, Bob, Charlie) are likely good; as evil I need a team including me or Diana to have a shot at sabotaging.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 passed clean with me, Bob, and Charlie, and the only change on Mission 3 was adding Diana before it failed, I’m most wary of including her right now. I’d prefer a team from some combo of me, Bob, Charlie, and maybe Eve.

I’m inclined to stick with the Mission 2 trio of me, Alice, and Charlie for this one, since that was our only 3-person clean team and the only change on the failed mission was adding Diana. If we really don’t want to fully lock Diana out yet, I’d rather see Eve tried later than risk her over a proven combo right now.

Sticking with the Mission 2 trio of Alice, Bob, and me makes the most sense right now; the only new variable on the failed Mission 3 was adding Diana, so I’d rather keep her off than start swapping in more unknowns. If we do change anything, I’d rather test Eve than bring Diana back in.

If you’re convinced I’m the variable from Mission 3, I get keeping me off, but I actually feel better about trying something like Alice, Bob, and Frank here than just auto-locking the exact Mission 2 trio off a single data point.
Given the board state, re-running the Mission 2 trio of Alice, Bob, and Charlie is the safest call right now; if that somehow fails, we can reassess and I’m fine being swapped in over Diana next.
Given how clean Mission 2 was, I’d stick with Alice, Bob, and Charlie here; if we learn more and *have* to swap later, I’d rather see Eve tested before bringing Diana back in.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Alice as Merlin: from the start she kept quietly steering teams away from Frank without ever really casing him, and after the Mission 3 fail she locked onto me as the problem off just one data point and then never pushed to “test” Frank at all. Bob’s my distant second place—his logic is clean but feels more like straightforward deduction, whereas Alice’s team preferences look like someone who already knew exactly which combo was safe.

I’m mostly with you on Alice: her “low‑drama, anchor off known success” line sounds like someone who already knew which anchors were actually safe, and she was remarkably comfortable sidelining me without ever needing to see me on a team. Bob’s logic tracks too cleanly with the revealed results to *rule him out*, but it reads more like good-town Bayesian thinking; Alice’s early, consistent comfort with the exact winning core feels a lot more like pre-knowledge.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From Mission 1 onward, Alice kept subtly steering toward what turned out to be the consistently successful core (herself, Bob, Charlie) while never needing to test Frank, and she grew immediately and firmly suspicious of me after a single failed mission that added only one new variable. Her team preferences read less like incremental deduction and more like someone who already knew which combinations were safe and which player (Frank) to quietly avoid, which strongly indicates Merlin-level pre-knowledge.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed to guide most of the team selections toward successful missions, especially keeping Diana off the final mission while still pushing for the right teams. However, I was too transparent in how confidently I cleared Bob and Charlie and how I kept subtle but consistent suspicion on Diana, which made me stand out as Merlin and allowed the assassin to correctly target me.

player_observations.Bob: Played straightforwardly and consistently approved good teams, which made him look genuinely townie without overexplaining his logic. His reactions to mission results felt natural, helping him avoid attracting suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into the information role vibe, projecting a bit of extra confidence that fit well with being Percival and helped shield Merlin somewhat early on. Occasionally looked almost too sure about certain reads, which could make him a future assassination target instead of a decoy.
player_observations.Diana: Blended very well into the good team early by accepting reasonable teams and not pushing overly hard, then used that trust to slip onto the failing mission. Her play as Mordred was subtle and disciplined, never panicking after the failed mission and keeping her tone steady.
player_observations.Eve: Flew under the radar and didn’t strongly drive team compositions, which kept them from being suspected heavily but also limited their influence on correcting course. Their low-key style made them appear more like a passive good player than a threat.
player_observations.Frank: Played Morgana convincingly by adopting a confident, somewhat ‘informed’ tone that could confuse perceptions between Merlin and Morgana. Coordinated well with the evil narrative around mission 3, and stayed just ambiguous enough to keep the assassination window open on the real Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped secure early successes, which should have made me a reliable anchor for team proposals. I could have pushed harder on analyzing the Mission 3 fail and been more vocal about constructing/defending specific worlds, especially around distinguishing Diana from the rest of the group.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, feeding just enough info to keep early missions clean while still looking somewhat plausible as a regular good. Her endgame composure under suspicion helped evil find her in the assassination phase.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into an active information-gathering style as Percival, often staying central to team discussions and missions. Their close alignment with Alice made them look very coordinated, which was good for mission success but may have contributed to Alice being read as a power role.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as Mordred, especially by being included on the failed Mission 3 without drawing lasting heat afterward. She managed to avoid becoming a default suspect despite being on the only fail, which was key to the evil team’s win.
player_observations.Eve: Played a quieter, low-impact good game, which kept them off most people’s radar both as a threat and as a strong source of information. Their neutrality made it harder for the table to confidently build or eliminate certain worlds.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, mirrored Merlin-like behavior effectively enough that the good team couldn’t clearly separate his signals from Alice’s. His positioning and apparent reasonableness in discussions helped create confusion about where the true information was coming from.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly read that Alice was a power role but didn’t do enough to protect her identity and misjudged how obvious her Merlin signals were to evil. I also could have been more vocal in shaping team comps after Mission 3’s fail to better test Diana and Frank instead of defaulting to previously safe teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very classic, talkative Merlin game—consistently nudging good teams without ever hard-pushing accusations, but her alignment consistency across all four missions made her look too clean and thus suspicious as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Steady and low-drama; he followed the emerging consensus and backed logically sound teams, which made him read generically good but not especially cleared or influential.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well by accepting early good results and only revealing her impact on Mission 3, then smoothly re-integrated into discussion without over-defending, which kept suspicion of her relatively muted.
player_observations.Eve: Quiet side-role energy—didn’t push many bold reads, but also didn’t create chaos, making her feel like background town and thus an easy player to leave off critical teams without much protest.
player_observations.Frank: Played a subtle Morgana, echoing reasonable logic and staying near Alice’s orbit just enough to plausibly contest the Merlin read without over-claiming it, which helped keep good confused about relative trust between them.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-profile enough that my presence on the successful first mission helped build trust, making my later participation in the failing Mission 3 less suspicious. I could improve by better coordinating visible suspicion with Frank/Morgana earlier, to create more plausible alternative Merlin candidates and make the endgame even safer.

player_observations.Alice: You played Merlin very subtly, guiding teams toward mostly safe lineups without drawing overt attention, but your consistent accuracy made you a high-probability Merlin read by the end. You balanced early trust-building with just enough deference to others’ suggestions to avoid looking too controlling.
player_observations.Bob: You played in a straightforward, logical way, backing reasonable teams and not overcomplicating the deductions. Your willingness to go on or approve teams without much drama made you look reliably good but not especially protective of Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: You acted like an engaged information-gatherer, often aligning with Alice’s reads, which fit well with a Percival identity once revealed. Your behavior suggested you trusted Alice more than others, but you didn’t push hard enough to misdirect evil about who you thought Merlin was.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed relatively low-impact in terms of table-shaping, which kept you from being widely suspected but also meant your reads didn’t heavily influence team choices. Your quieter style made it harder to infer your alignment, but also lessened your ability to shield Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: You played Morgana in a way that let Alice’s reads stay central, which limited how much confusion you generated around who might be Merlin. When you did contribute, your points were reasonable and not overly theatrical, which helped you blend in but didn’t fully capitalize on the Morgana–Merlin ambiguity.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and didn’t create extra chaos, which helped maintain trust in the early game. I could have been more active in questioning the logic around Mission 3 and in protecting Alice during the assassination phase by casting more doubt or offering alternative Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama Merlin game, guiding teams to three clean successes while revealing just enough suspicion to catch Diana on Mission 3 without overexposing—though the pattern of accurate team selections made her a prime assassination target.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward and trustworthy good role, accepting teams and decisions that looked reasonable and not pushing any wild narratives, which made him seem reliably good but not particularly protective of Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed a strong inclination to trust Alice and Bob, forming a core that went on most missions; as Percival, he seemed to heavily favor Alice as Merlin, which helped missions succeed but also reinforced the assassin’s read.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as Mordred by accepting early good teams and waiting until Mission 3 to slip in a single fail, creating uncertainty without causing a full breakdown of trust in any one player.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed off most key missions yet still influenced the endgame read, using Morgana’s presence to help frame Alice as visibly knowledgeable and thereby confirming her as Merlin in the assassin’s eyes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with fellow evil players by keeping my suspicion level low and allowing Merlin to feel comfortable enough to reveal themselves through their mission choices, which helped set up a clean assassination on Alice. I could improve by being a bit more proactive in subtly pushing alternative narratives about who Merlin might be, to create even more confusion among the good team without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin, guiding missions effectively while staying on successful teams, but the consistency of being on all the approved mission teams made you stand out as a key decision-maker. Your confidence in team selections was helpful for good but also gave evil a solid signal for the assassination.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a straightforward, trusting good player—willing to go on teams and not overcomplicate the logic. Your low-heat, cooperative style made you look reliably good but not especially power-role-like, which kept suspicion off you in the late game.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed signs of being an information role by being consistently central in the mid-game and aligning strongly with Alice’s decisions. Your participation in both the successful and failed missions, plus your comfort taking leadership, hinted at you being more than a generic good player.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Mordred by blending in and taking an early mission with Alice without causing trouble, helping evil stay hidden through the first half of the game. You let others talk more and avoided being the focal point of logic debates, which kept suspicion on the more vocal players instead.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet or low-impact in terms of steering team compositions, which made you read as a background good player. That low-profile presence helped ensure you were rarely considered for key information roles, and you didn’t interfere much with the social reads that evil was exploiting.
